questions.question: There ……………………… someone at the gate.
questions.description: When the noun/pronoun following there is singular, the verb is singular.

questions.question: There ………………………….. many mangoes on the tree.
questions.description: When the noun that follows there is plural, the verb is plural.

questions.question: There ………………………… many unemployed people in the country.
questions.description: When the noun that follows there is plural, the verb is plural.

questions.question: There ………………………. a cat on the roof.
questions.description: When the noun/pronoun following there is singular, the verb is singular.

questions.question: There …………………………. many writers like him.
questions.description: When the noun that follows there is plural, the verb is plural.

questions.question: There ……………………….. a lot of commotion in the street.
questions.description: When the noun/pronoun following there is singular, the verb is singular.

questions.question: There ……………………….. something behind the curtain.
questions.description: When the noun/pronoun following there is singular, the verb is singular.

questions.question: There ……………………………. many people interested in buying cars.
questions.description: When the noun that follows there is plural, the verb is plural.

questions.question: ………………………. there any birds in the cage?
questions.description: When the noun that follows there is plural, the verb is plural.

questions.question: There ………………………. few politicians who are really honest.
questions.description: When the noun that follows there is plural, the verb is plural.

questions.question: ………………………. there anybody who can solve this puzzle?
questions.description: When the noun/pronoun following there is singular, the verb is singular.

questions.question: There ……………………….. hardly anything to do.
questions.description: When the noun/pronoun following there is singular, the verb is singular.

questions.question: Sam as well as his friends …………………………. at the party.
questions.description: When you connect two subjects with as well as, the verb agrees with the first subject.

questions.question: Neither Susan nor Mira ………………………………… capable of doing this.
questions.description: When we connect two nouns with neither/nor, the verb agrees with the number and person of the second subject.

questions.question: One of my friends …………………………… gone to Africa.
questions.description: Use a singular verb after one of.

questions.question: Neither of us ……………………………. interested in this.
questions.description: When we connect two nouns with neither/nor, the verb agrees with the number and person of the second subject.

questions.question: Either you or he …………………………… mistaken.
questions.description: When we connect two nouns with either/or, the verb agrees with the number and person of the second subject.

questions.question: He along with his friends ………………………….. gone to the movies.
questions.description: When we connect two nouns with ‘along with’, the verb agrees with the first subject.

questions.question: Neither cheese nor butter …………………………… with me.
questions.description: When we connect two nouns with neither/nor, the verb agrees with the number and person of the second subject.

questions.question: The doctor as well as the nurses ……………………………… on a strike.
questions.description: When you connect two subjects with as well as, the verb agrees with the first subject.

questions.question: Neither John nor his brothers …………………………….. there.
questions.description: When we connect two nouns with neither/nor, the verb agrees with the number and person of the second subject.

questions.question: John or his brother …………………………… to do the shopping this week.
questions.description: When we connect two singular nouns with 'or', the verb is singular.

questions.question: The committee ………………………….. 12 members.
questions.description: Collective nouns are usually treated as singular.

questions.question: Both of his children …………………………… married.
questions.description: We use a plural verb after both.

questions.question: He asked me whether either of the applicants ……………….. suitable.
questions.description: We use a singular verb after either, neither, each, everyone and many a.

questions.question: Each of these minerals …………………. found in India.
questions.description: We use a singular verb after either, neither, each, everyone and many a.

questions.question: Many a man ……………………….. died at sea.
questions.description: We use a singular verb after either, neither, each, everyone and many a.

questions.question: Either you or he ……………………… mistaken.
questions.description: We use a singular verb after either, neither, each, everyone and many a.

questions.question: Neither food nor water …………………….. given to the captives.
questions.description: When two singular nouns are connected by neither...nor, the verb is singular.

questions.question: Physics …………………….. a branch of science.
questions.description: Names of subjects are always treated as singular.

questions.question: The news ……………………….. too good to be true.
questions.description: News is an uncountable noun in English and as such it is followed by a singular verb.

questions.question: Plutarch’s Lives ……………………… an interesting story.
questions.description: When the plural noun is the name of a book, magazine or movie, it is followed by a singular verb.

questions.question: The committee ……………………….. submitted its report.
questions.description: Collective nouns are usually treated as singular.

questions.question: Six miles …………………………… a long distance.
questions.description: When the plural noun denotes some specific quantity or amount considered as a whole, the verb is usually singular.

questions.question: Justice as well as mercy …………………… it.
questions.description: When two nouns are connected with as well as, the verb agrees with the first noun.

questions.question: The house with its contents …………………….. insured.
questions.description: When two nouns are connected with 'with', the verb agrees with the first noun.

questions.question: Our team ………………… going to lose the match.
questions.description: Collective nouns are normally used with singular verbs especially when we are talking about the group as a whole.

questions.question: A number of people ………………… tried to find the treasure.
questions.description: We normally use plural verbs with expressions like 'a number of people' or 'most of us'.

questions.question: The majority of criminals …………………. non-violent.
A lot of social problems ………………… caused by poverty.
questions.description: If we use a plural noun after 'a lot of', the verb is also plural.

questions.question: A couple of my friends ………………… going to open a travel agency.
One of my friends ……………….. going to Venezuela.
questions.description: Here the subject is the singular expression 'one', so we need a singular verb here.

questions.question: Wasps ..................... a serious problem in our garden.
questions.description: The noun 'wasps' is plural and hence it requires a plural verb.

questions.question: A good knowledge of three languages ..................... necessary for this job.
questions.description: Here the subject is the singular expression 'a good knowledge'.

questions.question: The police ……………….. looking for a balding man in his forties.
questions.description: The noun 'police' is always used with plural verbs.

questions.question: Many cattle ……………….. died because of the drought.
questions.description: The noun cattle is plural and hence it requires a plural verb.
